>>I think we need throw away all of these old
>>terms and replace them with a proper classification system, since (to me
>>anyway) all of these strategies are just variations on a theme.
>>    
>>
>
>That's probably a very cool idea, we could build in terms for the 
>various things we already identified as coming in 47 different 
>flavours, e.g. I had 8 different definitions for "modular" and we 
>have discussed several different forms of "co-evolving"...
>
>I'm going to post about 47 different "speciation" strategies in a 
>week or so (that's on top of the areas we already covered)...
>
>OTOH, to get any wide usage (and such a system isn't useful unless it 
>has wide usage) you probably need some big name to push it at 2 or 3 
>big conferences...
>  
>
Sure, but I just think that some of the terms in use right now are a bit 
vague and confusing. ES is a good example and in general I have to go 
and look these terms up to remind myself what they mean - and often I 
find that they aren't that well defined in the first place.


>>>[Search Slowdown]
>>>      
>>>
>>Generally speaking I can confirm this observation. I think in your case
>>the evaluation time is constant and it's the increasing complexity of
>>the solutions that consumes time, yes? which is how I arrived at the
>>phased pruning idea.
>>    
>>
>
>Not really.  I mean at first that is what it is, the initial 
>individuals are so simple that they take no time to evaluate. 
>
I should perhaps clarify what I mean here. I'm thinking about the 
distinction between the time spent by the nuts and bolts of the fitness 
function rather than the time spent activating the 'brain', whether that 
be an ANN, SLEAT network or whatever. So e.g. if we're evolving a 
bipedal walker then as the fitness improves, the actual fitness function 
code will take longer to execute because the walkers are walking 
further, the same is true of many evaluation schemes (game playing, pole 
balancing, etc).

This is seperate to the time spent activating the controller/brain, 
which also increases as the controller becomes more complex. And then of 
course the genetic operators take longer because the genomes they 
operate on are larger, decoding takes longer, etc. A triple whammy of 
performance degradation if you like.

Therefore your fitness scheme that evaluates all board positions takes 
the same amount of CPU time regardless of the genome geing evaluated, 
yes? But the fitness function taken as whole gets slower - because it 
includes activating the brain (for want of a better term).

>>I have to say that working with templates is a breath of fresh air, I
>>think this new framework is going to make the old one look positively
>>old hat!
>>    
>>
>
>Excellent!
>
>There may be some C# in my new job (not for a while, however), so if 
>I get familiar in it, I might be very interested in your new framework...
>  
>
<Sales Pitch Warning>

I may have already mentioned this but the newly released Visual Studio 
C# Express is available as a free download from microsoft (just do a 
google). This is built around the new .Net 2.0 engine/framework although 
others have reported that the existing SharpNEAT solution files import 
and compile with no problem.

Oh and there *will* be a fresh release of the existing sharpneat 
framework at some point that includes a re-organisation of the file/dir 
structure and support for plugging in experiments at load time, rather 
than compile time - thanks to Ricardo Mendez - plus a few other 
developments. E.g. Real Carbonneau reports some benefit to be had from 
reducing he connection weight mutation rate quite substantially and the 
use of alternative activation functions.

Ever forward :)

Colin.
